body.p: In May 2013 the College welcomed its first elected Board to be led by new President Dr Murray Patton. Information for members about each Director, including portfolio and email address is provided below. To email all Board member simultaneously please use board@ranzcp.org
Dr Murray Patton graduated from the University of Otago with a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MBChB) in 1981, and gained his Fellowship of the RANZCP in 1989.

Dr Patton has held senior roles in services in New Zealand and Australia. He is now Clinical Director of Mental Health and Addictions Services and Director of Area Mental Health Services with Waitemata District Health Board (DHB), which serves the largest district health board population in New Zealand. He is also currently acting as Clinical Advisor to the General Manager of Mental Health Services in Northland DHB, serving one of the smallest but most geographically dispersed DHB populations.

Dr Patton has practised predominantly in the public sector as an adult psychiatrist, while maintaining a small private consulting practice offering expert advice to the Health and Disability Commissioner and assisting with service reviews for other DHBs.

Dr Patton has taken on a number of roles within the RANZCP over many years, including most recently as a member of General Council (2009–2013), and chairing the Board of Practice, Policy and Partnerships (2009–2011). In 2012 he completed the Australian Institute of Company Directors Company Directors’ course.
Dr Patton took office as President for a 2-year term at the College’s Annual General Meeting in May 2013. Dr Patton can be contacted via murray.patton@ranzcp.org

Dr Hopwood graduated from the University of Melbourne in 1986 with a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MBBS), and gained his Fellowship of the RANZCP in 1994, along with a Masters of Psychological Medicine from Monash University. In 1997 he also completed a Doctor of Medicine (MD) from the University of Melbourne.

After working in the public health care system for many years, he now holds the positions of Professor of Psychiatry with Ramsay Health Care at the University of Melbourne and Clinical Director, Professorial Psychiatry Unit at the Albert Road Clinic.

He has contributed to a number of committees, including the Victorian Department of Human Services Bushfire Psychosocial Recovery Evaluation Advisory Committee, the Victorian Psychosurgery Review Board, the Commonwealth Department of Veterans’ Affairs National Clinical Advisory Group and the Multidisciplinary Panel for the Revision of the Australian NHMRC Guidelines for Acute Stress Disorder and Posttraumatic Stress Disorder. He is also Chairman of the Board of the Sumner Foundation, which provides advocacy, support and sector development for young people with acquired brain injuries living in nursing homes.

Professor Hopwood has held a number of roles with the College, most recently as Victorian Branch Chair (2009–2013). He was a member of General Council from 2007 to 2009 and a member of the Board of Research for 10 years. He is a member of the Faculty of Psychiatry of Old Age and the Section of Neuropsychiatry.
Professor Hopwood became President Elect in 2013 and will be President of the College from 2015–2017. Professor Hopwood Chairs the Audit Committee and the Members’ Advisory Council.
Professor Hopwood can be contacted via malcolm.hopwood@ranzcp.org

Dr Margaret Aimer graduated from the University of Auckland Medical School with a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MBChB) in 1983, having previously completed a Bachelor of Human Biology (1980), and was elected a Fellow of the RANZCP in 1994.

Dr Aimer has held a range of clinical positions with health services in New Zealand, including Clinical Director of Mental Health Services at Counties Manukau District Health Board from 2004 until 2011. She is now Head of Health System Improvement, Ko Awatea – Centre for Health System Innovation and Improvement for the Counties Manukau District Health Board in Auckland, running programs of work supporting system-wide change both nationally and locally. She is also Senior Clinical Director for Recovery Solutions, a large NGO provider. The majority of Dr Aimer’s clinical work has been with older people and adults, in both hospital and community settings. In 2010–2011 she was a member of the Health Workforce New Zealand Mental Health Services Review taskforce.

Dr Aimer has been a member of the Faculty of Old Age Psychiatry since 1994 and was Director of Training – Old Age Psychiatry from 1998–2001. Most recently, she was Deputy Chair, Board of Practice, Partnerships and Policy, overseeing the Partnerships and External Relations portfolio.
Dr Aimer was elected to the College Board in 2013 for a 3-year term. She Chairs the Education Committee. Dr Aimer can be contacted via margaret.aimer@ranzcp.org

Dr David Alcorn attained his RANZCP Fellowship in 1994. He has worked as a general and forensic psychiatrist in both the public and private sectors and has worked in inpatient and community/outpatient services. He also led a tertiary/quaternary general hospital for 4 years until 2013. As a result, he has first-hand experience of many of the systemic pressures on the Fellowship, consumers, carers and our health system.

He is passionate about consumer collaboration and driving system-wide improvements in safety, effectiveness, access and efficiency for consumers and their families, informed by the integrity, research and wisdom of the medical profession.

Dr Alcorn completed the Australian Institute of Company Directors Company Directors’ course in 2004 and has served on the boards of not-for-profit groups in the community sector (Bluecare Queensland), the research sector (Wesley Research Institute), the education sector (Postgraduate Medical Education Council of Queensland), and of professional membership organisations (General Council, RANZCP and Australian Medical Association Queensland).

He is a surveyor for the Australian Council on Healthcare Standards and a fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Medical Administrators and the Australian Institute of Company Directors. He has a Masters of Business Administration (University of Melbourne) and is an alumnus of the Harvard Business School (Advanced Management Program #183).
Dr Alcorn was elected to the College Board in 2013 for a 3-year term. He Chairs the Finance Committee. Dr Alcorn can be contacted via david.alcorn@ranzcp.org

Dr Kym Jenkins graduated from the University of Manchester (UK) in 1980 with a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MBChB) and initially specialised in general practice. After moving from the United Kingdom to Australia in 1986 she worked in general practice before commencing psychiatry training and completed her Fellowship with the RANZCP in 1998.

In addition to gaining a Masters of Psychological Medicine, Dr Jenkins pursued further studies in medical education, gaining a Masters of Education degree in 2008. Dr Jenkins has held a range of roles as a consultant psychiatrist in both the public and private sectors. She is currently Medical Director/Senior Clinician of the Victorian Doctors’ Health Program, runs a small private practice and is an adjunct Senior Lecturer at Monash University.

Dr Jenkins has had extensive involvement in psychiatry-related medical education, both within the RANZCP and externally. She has had roles within the College as an accredited examiner, trainer and assessor and has served as the Chair of the Committee for Examinations, Chair of the Fellowship Attainment Committee and Deputy Chair of the Board of Education. She has also been involved in the planning and development of the new (competency-based) Fellowship program since its inception and has chaired several of its working parties. Dr Jenkins was a member of General Council from 2005 to 2010.
Dr Jenkins was elected to the College Board in 2013 for a 3-year term. She Chairs the Membership Engagement Committee. Dr Jenkins can be contacted via kym.jenkins@ranzcp.org

Dr Peter Jenkins graduated from the University of Melbourne with a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MBBS) in 1980 and in 1995 gained Fellowship of the RANZCP, as well as the College’s Certificate of Satisfactory Completion of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Training.

He has practised predominantly in the public sector and is now the Director of Clinical Services with Eastern Health Child and Youth Mental Health Service, which serves those aged up to 25 living in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne.

Dr Jenkins has been involved with College activities over many years, including as a member of General Council (2007–2011), member and past secretary of the Faculty of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Committee, member of the Victorian Branch Committee and member of the Youth Special Interest Group Committee.
Dr Jenkins was elected to the College Board in 2013 for a 3-year term. He Chairs the Practice and Partnerships Committee. Dr Jenkins can be contacted via peter.jenkins@ranzcp.org

Associate Professor Victor Storm graduated from Monash University with a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MBBS) in 1976, gaining Fellowship of the RANZCP in 1986 and a Certificate of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry in 1988. He became a Fellow of the Australasian Faculty of Public Health Medicine in 1990. Subsequently, he completed a Master in Public Administration from Harvard University in 1993.

Currently employed as Director and Clinical Director of Mental Health Services at Sydney and South West Sydney Local Health District, Associate Professor Storm also holds appointments with a number of universities and is Consultant Psychiatrist to the Aboriginal Medical Service, Redfern.

He has been involved in health service planning and reviews by a range of organisations, including the NSW Mental Health Program Council, the NSW Mental Health Multicultural Implementation Committee and the NHMRC Working Party on Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder.

Associate Professor Storm has worked extensively in Asia and the Pacific as a consultant psychiatrist and has received a number of awards, including the Commemorative Medal of the National Association of Psychiatrists of Vietnam and the Mental Health Princess Award from HRH Princess Galyani Vadhana (Thailand).

Associate Professor Storm has had a wide range of roles with the College, including two periods on General Council (1994–2001 and 2011–2013). He has been a member of the Faculty of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry’s executive committee for many years and was Chair from 1993 to 2001. He is currently a member of the NSW Branch Committee and the World Psychiatric Association Section of Child Psychiatry Committee.

Associate Professor Storm was elected to the College Board in 2013 for a 3-year term. He Chairs the Corporate Governance and Risk Committee. Associate Professor Storm can be contacted via victor.storm@ranzcp.org
